CHILOSTOMATOUS: Of or pertaining to the Chilostoma.

LINGUISTICS: The science of languages, or of the origin, signification, andapplication of words; glossology.

EPENTHESIS: The insertion of a letter or a sound in the body of a word; as,the b in "nimble" from AS. nemol.

PLASTERY: Of the nature of plaster.The stone . . . is a poor plastery material. Clough.

JOHNNY: A sculpin. [Local cant] Johny Crapaud (, a jocose designationof a Frenchman, or of the French people, collectively.

WALY: An exclamation of grief. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]

THUNDERCLOUD: A cloud charged with electricity, and producing lightning andthunder.

BRAZENNESS: The quality or state of being brazen. Johnson.

DISCONTINUE: To interrupt the continuance of; to intermit, as a practice orhabit; to put an end to; to cause to cease; to cease using, to stop;to leave off.Set up their conventicles again, which had been discontinued. Bp.Burnet.I have discontinued school Above a twelvemonth. Shak.Taught the Greek tongue, discontinued before in these parts the spaceof seven hundred years. Daniel.They modify and discriminate the voice, without appearing todiscontinue it. Holder.

EUCALYPTOL: A volatile, terpenelike oil extracted from the eucalyptus, andconsisting largely of cymene.

WANNESS: The quality or state of being wan; a sallow, dead, pale color;paleness; pallor; as, the wanness of the cheeks after a fever.

CONTRASTIMULANT: Counteracting the effects of stimulants; relating to a courseof medical treatment based on a theory of contrastimulants.-- n. (Med.)

PALL-MALL: A game formerly common in England, in which a wooden ball wasdriven with a mallet through an elevated hoop or ring of iron. Thename was also given to the mallet used, to the place where the gamewas played, and to the street, in London, still called Pall Mall.[Written also pail-mail and pell-mell.] Sir K. Digby. Evelyn.

COLLOCATION: The act of placing; the state of being placed with somethingelse; disposition in place; arrangement.The choice and collocation of words. Sir W. Jones.

ABSORBEDLY: In a manner as if wholly engrossed or engaged.

FURZELING: An English warbler (Melizophilus provincialis); -- called alsofurze wren, and Dartford warbler.

OCCRUSTATE: To incrust; to harden. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.

REFRIGERATE: To cause to become cool; to make or keep cold or cool.

LASS: A youth woman; a girl; a sweetheart.

JETTISON: The throwing overboard of goods from necessity, in order tolighten a vessel in danger of wreck.

OPAL: A mineral consisting, like quartz, of silica, but inferior toquartz in hardness and specific gravity.

REGENERATORY: Having power to renew; tending to reproduce; regenerating. G.S. Faber.

OPAH: A large oceanic fish (Lampris quttatus), inhabiting theAtlantic Ocean. It is remarkable for its brilliant colors, which arered, green, and blue, with tints of purple and gold, covered withround silvery spots. Called also king of the herrings.

AGRAPPES: Hooks and eyes for armor, etc. Fairholt.

TOMBAC: An alloy of copper and zinc, resembling brass, and containingabout 84 per cent of copper; -- called also German, or Dutch, brass.It is very malleable and ductile, and when beaten into thin leaves issometimes called Dutch metal. The addition of arsenic makes whitetombac. [Written also tombak, and tambac.]

LIGAMENT: Composing a ligament; of the nature of a ligament; binding; as,a strong ligamentous membrane.

LASH: ,. v. i. To ply the whip; to strike; to uttercensure orsarcastic language.To laugh at follies, or to lash at vice. Dryden.To lash out, to strike out wildly or furiously.

SYNCYTIUM: Tissue in which the cell or partition walls are wholly wantingand the cell bodies fused together, so that the tissue consists of acontinuous mass of protoplasm in which nuclei are imbedded, as inordinary striped muscle.

SILKEN: To render silken or silklike. Dyer.

POSTOBLONGATA: The posterior part of the medulla oblongata. B. G. Wilder.

DISPOSITIVELY: In a dispositive manner; by natural or moral disposition.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.Do dispositively what Moses is recorded to have done literally, . . .break all the ten commandments at once. Boyle.

AARD-VARK: An edentate mammal, of the genus Orycteropus, somewhatresembling a pig, common in some parts of Southern Africa. It burrowsin the ground, and feeds entirely on ants, which it catches with itslong, slimy tongue.

SIPHUNCULAR: Of or pertaining to the siphuncle.

PYGMY: One of a fabulous race of dwarfs who waged war with the cranes,and were destroyed.

INTENIBLE: Incapable of holding or containing. [Obs.]This captious and intenible sieve. Shak.

FILIATION: The assignment of a bastard child to some one as its ather;affiliation. Smart.

ICHOROUS: Of or like ichor; thin; watery; serous; sanious.

WATERMELON: The very large ovoid or roundish fruit of a cucurbitaceousplant (Citrullus vulgaris) of many varieties; also, the plant itself.The fruit sometimes weighs many pounds; its pulp is usually pink incolor, and full of a sweet watery juice. It is a native of tropicalAfrica, but is now cultivated in many countries. See Illust. ofMelon.

PHOCACEAN: Any species of Phoca; a seal.

THOROUGHLY: In a thorough manner; fully; entirely; completely.

REVERSIONER: One who has a reversion, or who is entitled to lands ortenements, after a particular estate granted is terminated.Blackstone.

DIES NON: A day on which courts are not held, as Sunday or any legalholiday.

LIGHT-HEARTED: Free from grief or anxiety; gay; cheerful; merry.-- Light"-heart`ed*ly, adv.-- Light"-heart"ed*ness, n.

WINTER: To pass the winter; to hibernate; as, to winter in Florida.Because the haven was not commodious to winter in, the more partadvised to depart thence. Acts xxvii. 12.

SEPHARDIC: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the Jews (the Sephardim,also called Spanish or Portuguese Jews) descended from Jewishfamilies driven from Spain by the Inquisition.

WITHAL: With; -- put after its object, at the end of sentence or clausein which it stands. [Obs.]This diamond he greets your wife withal. Shak.Whatsoever uncleanness it be that a man shall be defiled withal. Lev.v. 3.

CRUCIBLE STEEL: Cast steel made by fusing in crucibles crude or scrap steel,wrought iron, and other ingredients and fluxes.

REDARGUTION: The act of redarguing; refutation. [Obs. or R.] Bacon.

SEPHARDIM: Jews who are descendants of the former Jews of Spain andPortugal. They are as a rule darker than the northern Jews, and havemore delicate features.

SOPITION: The act of putting to sleep, or the state of being put tosleep; sleep. [Obs.]Dementation and sopition of reason. Sir T. Browne.

TRAM: A silk thread formed of two or more threads twisted together,used especially for the weft, or cross threads, of the best qualityof velvets and silk goods.

NEEDLER: One who makes or uses needles; also, a dealer in needles. PiersPlowman.

ATOMICALLY: In an atomic manner; in accordance with the atomic philosophy.

PHYTOLITHOLOGIST: One versed in phytolithology; a paleobotanist.

ASTARBOARD: Over to the starboard side; -- said of the tiller.

DISFLESH: To reduce the flesh or obesity of. [Obs.] Shelton.

WINCE: The act of one who winces.

WINCH: To wince; to shrink; to kick with impatience or uneasiness.

FRETUM: A strait, or arm of the sea.

LIMA: The capital city of Peru, in South America. Lima bean. (Bot.)(a) A variety of climbing or pole bean (Phaseolus lunatus), which hasvery large flattish seeds. (b) The seed of this plant, much used forfood.-- Lima wood (Bot.), the beautiful dark wood of the South Americantree Csalpinia echinata.

BEGUINAGE: A collection of small houses surrounded by a wall and occupiedby a community of Beguines.

MADID: Wet; moist; as, a madid eye. [R.] Beaconsfield.

CAMERA OBSCURA: An apparatus in which the image of an external object orobjects is, by means of lenses. thrown upon a sensitized plate orsurface placed at the back or an extensible darkened box or chambervariously modifled; -- commonly called simply the camera.

KISSINGCRUST: The portion of the upper crust of a loaf which has touchedanother loaf in baking. Lamb.A massy fragment from the rich kissingcrust that hangs like a frettedcornice from the upper half of the loaf. W. Howitt.

LEPTUS: The six-legged young, or larva, of certain mites; -- sometimesused as a generic name. See Harvest mite, under Harvest.

MADIA: A genus of composite plants, of which one species (Madiasativa) is cultivated for the oil yielded from its seeds by pressure.This oil is sometimes used instead of olive oil for the table.

MONOTHALAMAN: A foraminifer having but one chamber.

EXPLICATOR: One who unfolds or explains; an expounder; an explainer.

MONOGENOUS: Of or pertaining to monogenesis; as, monogenous, or asexual,reproduction.

DEMAND: To call into court; to summon. Burrill.

CARAPATO: A south American tick of the genus Amblyamma. There are severalspecies, very troublesome to man and beast.

INTELLECTUAL: The intellect or understanding; mental powers or faculties.Her husband, for I view far round, not nigh, Whose higherintellectual more I shun. Milton.I kept her intellectuals in a state of exercise. De Quincey.

ACETYLENE: A gaseous compound of carbon and hydrogen, in the proportion oftwo atoms of the former to two of the latter. It is a colorless gas,with a peculiar, unpleasant odor, and is produced for use as anilluminating gas in a number of ways, but chiefly by the action ofwater on calcium carbide. Its light is very brilliant. Watts.

PROPAGULUM: A runner terminated by a germinating bud.

SAPODILLA: A tall, evergeen, tropical American tree (Achras Sapota); also,its edible fruit, the sapodilla plum. [Written also sapadillo,sappadilo, sappodilla, and zapotilla.] Sapodilla plum (Bot.), thefruit of Achras Sapota. It is about the size of an ordinary quince,having a rough, brittle, dull brown rind, the flesh being of a dirtyyellowish white color, very soft, and deliciously sweet. Called alsonaseberry. It is eatable only when it begins to be spotted, and ismuch used in desserts.

TWIRL: To move or turn round rapidly; to whirl round; to move and turnrapidly with the fingers.See ruddy maids, Some taught with dexterous hand to twirl the wheel.Dodsley.No more beneath soft eve's consenting star Fandango twirls his jocundcastanet. Byron.

TWIRE: A twisted filament; a thread. [Obs.] Locke.
